subject: RE: [junit] Newbie
msgSnippet: unit3.5 doc faq faq.htm JUnit Frequently Asked Questions Can t find my test class when using a TestRunner When you are getting a Can t find TestClass error
messageBody:
unit3.5\doc\faq\faq.htm
JUnit Frequently Asked Questions
Can't find my test class when using a TestRunner
When you are getting a "Can't find 'TestClass'" error message when you try
to run your test with a TestRunner make sure that:
* the junit.jar isn't installed in the extension directory of your JDK
installation. The junit.jar has to be on the class path.
* the Test class you are trying to run is on the class path.
Notice, that the tests that come with the JUnit distribution are not
included inside the junit.jar but they reside in the installation directory.
Therefore make sure that the JUnit installation directory is on the class
path.


Michael Finney
Sun Certified Programmer for the Java 2 Platform
Sun Certified Developer for the Java 2 Platform


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Chris Tillman [SMTP:toff@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, February 14, 2001 4:24 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Newbie
>
> We're just trying out jUnit. We put together a small test case class,
> based on the example on the web page. It compiles, but it doesn't run,
> complaining that it can't find the TestCase class. We put the junit.jar
> into our jdk1.3/jre/lib/ext folder, is there something else we need to do?
>
> import junit.framework.Test;
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> import junit.framework.TestSuite;
>
> public class QuickDexTest extends TestCase {
>
> private Quickdex q;
>
> public QuickDexTest(String name) {
> super(name);
> }
>
> protected void setUp() {
> q = new Quickdex();
> }
>
> protected void tearDown() {
> q = null;
> }
>
> public void testnew() {
> String s = q.getCardText();
> assertEquals( "TriedEmpty", s, null );
> }
>
>
> public static Test suite() {
>
> //
> // Reflection is used here to add all
> // the testXXX() methods to the suite.
> //
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(QuickDexTest.class);
>
> //
> // Alternatively, but prone to error when adding more
> // test case methods...
> //
> // TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> // suite.addTest(new ShoppingCartTest("testEmpty"));
> // suite.addTest(new ShoppingCartTest("testProductAdd"));
> // suite.addTest(new ShoppingCartTest("testProductRemove"));
> // suite.addTest(new ShoppingCartTest("testProductNotFound"));
> //
>
> return suite;
> }
>
> public static void main(String args[]) {
> // String[] testCaseName = {QuickDexTest.class.getName()};
> System.out.println( "Doesn't print this" );
> // junit.swingui.TestRunner.main(testCaseName);
> }
>
> }
>
